title: Chaos at Euston Station as all trains halted due to trespasser
text:
The travel hub was rammed with commuters after all trains were brought to a stop (Picture: PA)

Commuters travelling in and out of London Euston have been facing major disruption as police dealt with a trespasser.

All services from the central London transport hub were suspended during rush hour while authorities responded to the incident in Wembley Central station.

Some passengers were stuck for hours inside train carriages and were handed emergency glow sticks as operators turned off the lights to preserve power.

Metropolitan Police, London Fire Brigade and British Transport Police (BTP) were called to Wembley Central station shortly before 4.30pm to reports of concern for a man’s welfare.

He was treated for injuries at the scene before being taken to hospital by road, despite an air ambulance being dispatched in case it was needed.

Ive been stuck on an airless, humid train just north of #Euston for well over an hour. They’ve now had to turn the emergency power off to ensure enough electricity to restart the engines when the time comes. Crew now giving out emergency light sticks. This is ridiculous. pic.twitter.com/zaK4ny28Zm — Emma Dunn (@MrsEmmaDunn) October 25, 2019

We have lights! We have air! We have functioning toilets! And we’re on the move! 🤪 pic.twitter.com/nZ1rrtVwdI — Emma Dunn (@MrsEmmaDunn) October 25, 2019

Police say the man was taken to hospital by road (Picture: PA)

First day back commuting after a few months working from home and all trains cancelled at #Euston due to people on the track. pic.twitter.com/rZfjwO4cI8 — Ryan Morrison (@RyanMorrisonJer) October 25, 2019

Pictures taken by commuters at London Euston show the station concourse packed with people.

Network Rail said the West Coast main line was closed for a number of hours this evening while emergency services dealt with the incident.

The railway firm said all lines have been reopened, but they warned of ‘serious disruption’ for passengers until end of service tonight.

Managing director for Network Rail’s West Coast main line south route James Dean said: ‘Our specialist teams have been working with the emergency services to deal with a serious trespass incident this evening near Wembley Central.

‘We thank people for their patience while we try to get services back up and running.’
